name: WILD BLUE FLAX
description: stigma capitate (headed); plant produces many branches from the base; styles of same length on different plants.
habitat: dry slopes, forest clearings, roadsides.

name: WILD ONION
common_name: plains onion, early onion, textile onion
description: inflorescence (flower cluster) erect; leaves 2 per scape (leafless flower stalk).
habitat: dry slopes and hillsides.

name: THINLEAF ALDER
description: scales of the carpellate (female) catkin thick and woody, resembling a small pine cone; leaves wrinkled; pith triangular in cross-section.
habitat: streambanks and pond borders.

name: SASKATOON SERVICEBERRY
description: upright, arching branches form a rounded crown; leaves broadly ovate (egg-shaped), sharply rounded at the base; flowers in axillary (where the leaf joins the stem) clusters; leaves and twigs glabrous (hairless) in age.
habitat: forested parts of mountains.

name: YELLOW STONECROP
description: leaves succulent (fleshy), in basal (at the plant base) clusters, often deciduous (falling off, not persistent throughout the year) before anthesis (opening of the flower).
habitat: rocky ground at 5,000 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: MEADOW ANEMONE
description: flowers solitary; achenes appressed-pubescent (with flat-lying hairs).
habitat: moist areas, meadows and streamsides.

name: DWARF  PUSSYTOES
description: usually with leafy stolons; leaves in basal rosette, white-tomentose on both sides (densely covered with thick-wooly hairs with no distinct orientation); phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - surrounding composite head) white or sometimes pinkish tips.
habitat: open montane forests.

name: KINNIKINNICK
description: leaves green on both sides; flowers urn-shaped.
habitat: gravelly or rocky forest openings and slopes at 7,000 to 11,500 feet.

name: FRINGED MOUNTAIN SAGE
common_name: fringed sage, silver sage, wormwood, pasture sage
description: leaves finely dissected, silvery-hairy; flowering stems erect.
habitat: dry meadows and slopes at 3,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: PRAIRIE SAGE
description: leaves silver white to greenish.
habitat: dry plains, roadcuts at 4,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: GUNNISON MARIPOSA
description: cup-shaped flower with 3 petals and 3 sepals; petals with dark hairy spot at their base.
habitat: aspen groves, meadows on the Eastern Slope

name: HAREBELL
description: corolla lobed only about 1/3; stems over 2 dm tall; flowers several per stem.
habitat: dry mountain slopes at lower to middle altitudes (7,500 to 11,500 feet).

name: MUSK THISTLE
description: heads with disk flowers only; pappus (extension of the ovary in sunflower family) barbellate (with short barbs); outer phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - that subtend a composite flower head) spreading-reflexed (bent backwards).
habitat: neglected fields, overgrazed meadows and roadsides.

name: FOOTHILLS PAINTBRUSH
description: calyx incised equally above and below; bracts (small leaf-like structures) broad and more conspicuous than calyx (sepals); leaves and stems tomentose (covered with wooly, multidirectional hairs); bracts orange.
habitat: grasslands of the foothills from Rocky Flats south; South Park.

name: WYOMING PAINTBRUSH
description: leaves linear, bracts red; calyx (ring of sepals) incised much more deeply below than above.
habitat: open meadows, forest openings, aspen groves, sagebrush at 4,000 to 10,500 feet elevation.

name: BUCKBRUSH
description: stamens opposite (attached in front of) the petals.
habitat: foothills and dry montane forests at 5,000 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: MOUSE-EAR CHICKWEED
description: floral stems with tufts of sterile shoots in leaf axils (angle where leaves join stems); bracts (small leaf-like structures) of the inflorescence (flower cluster) with scarious (dry, thin, papery) margins.
habitat: meadows and openings in pine forests.

name: MOUNTAIN MAHOGANY
description: leaves densely pubescent (hairy) underneath.
habitat: dry, rocky slopes at 4,500 to 9,000 feet.

name: BLUE GRAMA
description: spike forms at the end of the rachis (axis of the flower); long hairs at the collar (where the blade joins the sheath - the part that surrounds the stem - of a grass leaf).
habitat: grasslands of the plains, foothills, and intermountain parks at 3,200 to 9,700 feet elevation.

name: BLUE  MUSTARD
description: basal (at base of the plant) leaves are dentate (toothed with teeth projecting outward rather than forward).
habitat: fallow fields

name: SPRING BEAUTY
description: one or more basal leaves; cauline (stem) leaves lance-linear (long and narrowly lance-shaped).
habitat: pine forests in foothills of the Front Range.

name: BLUE-EYED MARY
description: small widely branched plant with  maroon color on the stems and on the underside of the leaves.
habitat: open forests, disturbed areas.

name: TINY TRUMPET
description: leaves lanceolate (lance-shaped); flowers in a dense terminal cluster surrounded by enlarged, leaf-like bracts (small leaf-like structures).
habitat: roadsides, grasslands, disturbed areas.

name: BASTARD-TOADFLAX
description: leaves alternate (one at each node or point of attachment to the stem), bluish-green.
habitat: dry, sandy slopes, open woods, sagebrush ecosystems.

name: BRANCHING ERIGERON
description: flowers numerous and pinkish; pappus (hair-like extension of the ovary) of ray and disk flowers alike; stem pubescence (hairs) widely spreading; stems with relatively few branches.
habitat: ruderal (disturbed) areas and gravelly floodplains.

name: WHIPLASH DAISY
common_name: whiplash erigeron, trailing daisy, trailing fleabane
description: stolons ( horizontal stems that take root as in the strawberry) rooting at the tips; stem hairs appressed (lying flat); pappus (hairlike extension of the ovary) of 2 rows of bristles of different lengths.
habitat: dry meadows at 6,500 to 10,500 feet elevation.

name: SULPHUR FLOWER
description: grows in broad, loose mats; perianth (petals and sepals) narrowed at the base to a stipe (stalk) and externally glabrous (smooth).
habitat: forest openings, dry meadows, rocky slopes at 5,000 to 11,500 feet.

name: REDSTEM FILAREE
description: carpel (seed pod section) tails hairy on inner side; leaves pinnately compound.
habitat: disturbed sites

name: WESTERN WALLFLOWER
description: siliques (mustard fruits) and pedicels (stalks) densely gray-pubescent (hairy); siliques spreading at a wide angle to the stem.
habitat: open areas, slopes, meadows, valleys at 4,500 to 12,500 feet elevation.

name: GREEN GENTIAN
description: fleshy leaves in whorls; blooming plant tall, up to 6 ft.; flowers greenish-white.
habitat: pine forests and meadows.

name: BLANKETFLOWER
description: grows in clumps with erect or spreading stems; pappus (extension of the ovary) twice as long as the basal scale; leaves stiff-hairy.
habitat: meadows, hillsides, open areas at 7,000 to 9,500 feet elevation.

name: BEDSTRAW
description: leaves lanceolate (lance-shaped), blunt-tipped, 4 at a node (point on a stem where leaves or branches occur); inflorescence (flower cluster) pyramidal.
habitat: moist meadows and woodlands.

name: SCARLET GAURA
description: flowers with parts in fours; inferior ovary (petals attached at top of ovary); stem ascending, seldom erect.
habitat: dry grasslands, roadsides, sagebrush, lower altitudes.

name: PARRY GERANIUM
description: plants with many hairy stems, these often sprawling.
habitat: dry slopes, meadows, forest openings.

name: GUMWEED
description: cauline leaves oblong and sessile by a broad, clasping base; pappus (extension of the ovary) bristles smooth; phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - on the lower portion of the composite head) recurved and sticky.
habitat: roadsides, fields, disturbed areas.

name: STICKSEED FORGET-ME-NOT
description: flower clusters arising from leaf axils (angle between leaves and stem).
habitat: forest clearings, slopes, roadsides.

name: COMMON SUNFLOWER
description: phyllaries (exterior bracts - small leaf-like structures - of composite heads) hispid-ciliate (clothed with stiff bristle-like hairs along the margins); phyllaries with acuminate tips (drawn out into a long tip); leaves ovate.
habitat: roadsides, fields.

name: BUSH SUNFLOWER
common_name: dwarf sunflower, perennial sunflower, little sunflower
description: leaves with petioles (stalks), mostly opposite (arising in pairs from same points on stem), ovate (egg-shaped); plant many-stemmed from base.
habitat: canyons, hillsides, roadsides.

name: COMMON ALUMROOT
description: stamens shorter than the sepals.
habitat: cliffs and rock outcrops.

name: ROCK SPIREA
description: flowers in terminal, many-flowered panicles (repeatedly branched flower clusters).
habitat: shaded cliff-faces, rocky slopes, hillsides, riverbottoms at 4,500 to 11,000 feet.

name: FENDLER WATERLEAF
description: leaves with sharply serrate (with forward-pointing teeth, like a saw) lobes.
habitat: streamside woodlands.

name: FAIRY TRUMPET
common_name: skyrocket, scarlet gilia (red form), white gilia
description: ovary with 3 locules (compartments); corolla (petals) salverform (with a long narrow tube opening into a wider cup i.e. trumpet-shaped).
habitat: gravelly open areas.

name: PRICKLY LETTUCE
description: pappus (extension of the ovary) bright white; leaf margins and/or midrib and veins spiny.
habitat: fields, gardens, disturbed areas.

name: SAND LILY
description: leaves grasslike; tepals (undifferentiated petals and sepals) united into a tube.
habitat: grasslands

name: PORTER LOVAGE
description: ultimate leaf lobes with many lateral veins as conspicuous as mid-vein; plant over 1 meter tall; flower cluster convex.
habitat: ravines, forest openings, aspen groves.

name: BROAD-LEAVED DALMATIAN TOADFLAX
description: leaves ovate (egg-shaped), glabrous (hairless) and glaucous (contains white waxy covering); corolla (collective term for petals) spurred.
habitat: disturbed areas; meadows.

name: BUTTER AND EGGS
description: leaves glabrous (smooth, hairless) and glaucous (contains white waxy covering).
habitat: open areas around former homesteads.

name: NARROW-LEAF PUCCOON
common_name: fringed gromwell, fringed puccoon, narrowleaf gromwell, narrowleaf stoneseed, puccoon
description: corolla (petals) tube 3 - 4 times longer than the calyx (sepals); corolla salverform (trumpet-shaped); corolla lobes fringed.
habitat: dry slopes and valleys.

name: SALT-AND-PEPPER
description: red anthers; grayish leaves.
habitat: plains, outwash mesas and foothills of the Front Range.

name: SILVERY LUPINE
description: tip of keel (lower petal in pea family) long and slender, erect or slanting forward; leaves are palmately compound (divided like a hand); leaflets often conduplicate (folded lengthwise).
habitat: open forests, hillsides and slopes.

name: CREEPING HOLLYGRAPE
common_name: Oregon grape, holly-grape, creeping oregon grape
description: above-ground stem short or lacking; leaflets broad with a few spiny teeth.
habitat: uplands and open coniferous forests.

name: FALSE SOLOMON SEAL
common_name: claspleaf solomon's plume, many-flowered false solomon seal
description: leaves clasping and broadly oval; flowers numerous in a dense panicle (branched flower cluster with stalked flowers).
habitat: streamsides, moist meadows and gulches.

name: WILD LILY-OF-THE-VALLEY
common_name: star solomon's seal; star solomon's plume, few-flowered false solomon seal
description: flowers in a raceme (stalked flowers along a main axis).
habitat: shady, moist areas in the forested mountains.

name: CHEESEWEED
description: flower pedicels (stalks) longer than the calyx (ring of sepals); plants procumbent (trailing on the ground).
habitat: gardens, lawns, cultivated areas, waste places.

name: FOOTHILL MERTENSIA
description: leaves with less than 2 pairs of prominent veins in stem leaves; filaments attached near the top of the cylindrical corolla tube and projecting beyond the junction of the tube and expanded portion of the flower.
habitat: dry, sunny fields and slopes.

name: SNOWBALL SAXIFRAGE
description: leaves rhomboid (shaped like an equilateral parallelogram), tapering to a short, broad petiole (leaf stalk).
habitat: open areas and rocky slopes that are seasonally moist in spring.

name: HORSEMINT
description: corolla (petals) two-lipped, more than 10 mm., rose-pink; fertile stamens 2.
habitat: streamsides, canyonsides, ravines and meadows.

name: BLAZINGSTAR
common_name: giant evening star, ten-petaled blazingstar, moonflower, large evening star
description: petals 2 to 3 inches long, 0.5 to 1 inch wide, not overlapping in anthesis (flowering), cream-colored; bracts (small leaf-like structures) partly fused to ovary wall.
habitat: disturbed soils, shaley or sandy hillsides, canyon walls, prairie slopes and sandstone outcrops along the base of the Front Range.

name: PRICKLY-PEAR CACTUS
description: pads very spiny, not wrinkled; fruits dry and withering soon after ripening.
habitat: sunny, rocky slopes at 3,500 to 7,200 feet elevation.

name: BOULDER RASPBERRY
description: leaves 1 to 2.5 inches wide with rounded lobes.
habitat: canyons of the Front Range, Arkansas Valley and San Luis Valley.

name: LAMBERT LOCO
description: keel (lower boat-shaped petal in the pea family) tip is pointed; calyx with appressed (lying flat) hairs; some of foliage hairs dolabriform (2-armed or pick-like).
habitat: grasslands of the plains, mountain parks and foothills at 4,500 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: MOUNTAIN BALL CACTUS
description: mature plant shaped and sized like a small grapefruit; tubercles (nipple-like projecting bodies) which cover stem surface are not grooved on upper side.
habitat: rocky, dry canyons and slopes at 4,800 to 9,000 feet elevation.

name: ONE-SIDED PENSTEMON
description: leaves glaucous (contains white waxy covering).
habitat: sandy slopes, roadsides.

name: ROCKY MOUNTAIN NINEBARK
description: flowers in umbellate clusters (stalked flowers arising from the same point); leaves palmately lobed; shredded bark.
habitat: gulches, rocky slopes, forest openings.

name: PONDEROSA PINE
description: needles in packages (fascicles) of 3 or 2; female cones large, up to 6 inches long; male cones up to 2 inches long.
habitat: exposed hillsides, mesas, and south-facing slopes.

name: LEAFY JACOB'S LADDER
description: corolla (whorl of petals) campanulate (bell-shaped); leaves mostly cauline (on stem); leaflets pubescent (hairy).
habitat: streamsides and meadows.

name: ASPEN
description: tree with smooth greenish or whitish bark; leaves quake in breeze due to flattened petiole (leaf stem).
habitat: moist slopes, streamsides, burned areas at 5,000 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: SULFUR CINQUEFOIL
description: leaves digitately compound (divided like a hand), coarsely toothed; annual or short-lived perennial; pubescence (hairs) of short glandular hairs and long, pilose (sparse, long, soft) hairs.
habitat: trailsides, roadsides, disturbed areas.

name: JAMES STARWORT
description: dark colored anthers are visible against petals; leaves lanceolate; plant glandular-pubescent (sticky-hairy).
habitat: forest edges, meadows, slopes.

name: PASQUE FLOWER
description: tepals (undifferentiated petals and sepals) overlapping; upper stem leaves form a whorl below the flower; leaves and stems pubescent (hairy).
habitat: open forests at 8,500 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: THREE-LEAF SUMAC
description: arching branches form dense, rounded shrub.  Red, hairy fruits; 3-parted leaves resemble poison ivy, to which skunkbrush is related, on a smaller scale.
habitat: canyonsides and rimrock at 4,000 to 8,000 feet elevation.l

name: MOUNTAIN GOOSEBERRY
description: stems with both prickles and spines; hypanthium (fused bases of stamens, petals and sepals) tubular.
habitat: shaded, moist areas at 6,000 to 10,000 feet elevation.

name: WOODS ROSE
description: leaflets 5 - 7; flowering stems with broad-based thorns, occasional bristles; sepals 2 mm wide at base.
habitat: valleys, gulches, trailsides at 6,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: WILD RED RASPBERRY
description: stems with prickles; leaves glaucous (contains white waxy covering) underneath.
habitat: moist forests and slopes.

name: SKULLCAP
description: leaves on the middle of the stem entire (without indentations).
habitat: gravelly, dry openings in pine forests.

name: EARLY SPRING SENECIO
common_name: common spring senecio, lambstongue groundsel, tall golden ragwort
description: pubescent (hairy), losing most pubescence in age; terminal head shorter than others.
habitat: moist meadows and slopes.

name: FENDLER MEADOWRUE
description: flowers mostly unisexual (either male or female); anthers much longer than wide; upper and lower edges of fruits mostly convex.
habitat: meadows, aspen groves from 5,000 to 9,500 feet elevation.

name: YELLOW SALSIFY
description: flowers shorter than the phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - below a composite flower head); peduncles (stalk of a flower cluster) swollen in fruit.
habitat: dry, hot valleys.

name: NUTTALL VIOLET
description: leaves narrowly lanceolate (lance-shaped) or lance-elliptic (oval), at least 3 times long as wide.
habitat: meadows, open slopes, often blooming in the protection of rocks at 5,000 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: YUCCA
description: flowers erect, drooping only in age; flowers in simple, narrow panicles (repeatedly branched flower cluster with stalked flowers).
habitat: rocky areas on the plains and foothills; found up to 8,500 feet elevation.
